sp.p: If the gentleman is an attorney, as I am told, I ſhould like to know whether he would be ſuffered to go on in this way in the courts of Weſtminſter-Hall?

sp.speaker: Lord Juſtice Clerk.
sp.p: It is certainly not a queſtion ſit for the witneſs to anſwer.

sp.speaker: Mr. Margarot.
sp.p: Have you any mode of diſtinguiſhing thoſe papers found in my trunk from thoſe that belonged to Mr. Gerald in the ſame trunk?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot ſay.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Then it may happen that you may have intermixed a paper of Mr. Gerald's and a paper of mine?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No; they were taken down diſtinctly, and marked with your own initials in your own preſence.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who arranged the papers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I arranged them in your preſence; I took them out at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Lord Juſtice Clerk.
sp.p: Did you not ſay, the Pannel picked out his papers and Mr. Gerald his?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; there was a paper put in, and all below that belonged to the Pannel.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did I not obſerve to you at the time, that being in an inn, we could not be anſwerable for what papers were found in our room?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I dare ſay you did.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did I not ſay, that even the meſſenger might bring that paper, if he thought proper, and huſtle them into the trunk at once?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: So you did.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: By what means are you certain, that the papers which you found in Mr. Skirving's poſſeſſion were minutes of the convention?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: From various circumſtances; but I ſubmit again to the court, whether it is proper to anſwer that?

sp.speaker: Lord Juſtice Clerk.
sp.p: Yes; you muſt give anſwers to legal queſtions.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The minutes were eſtabliſhed to be minutes of the Convention, by ſome of the members.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You accompanied the Sheriff to Mr. Laing's room.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did I ſay any thing to you at the time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; you was the firſt perſon that called to me, handed me a motion, and deſired I would read it; I told him I had nothing to do with it: it was a motion to petition the King, or ſomething of that kind.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you recollect the Sheriff Subſtitute ſaying, that he acted by orders?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot ſay; but he certainly told you, he came for the expreſs purpoſe of diſmiſſing that meeting, and that you muſt do no buſineſs as a Britiſh Convention.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did I not ſpeak to you; and you afterwards anſwered me, that you was doing your duty?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; by attending the Sheriffs.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You ſay that the meeting ended with prayer; can you recollect that prayer?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Does beginning and cloſing a meeting, for obtaining a reform in Parliament, with prayer, apply to the word Sedition?

sp.speaker: Lord Juſtice Clerk.
sp.p: That is a very improper queſtion.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the petition for the warrant ſtate, that I had met with others in Laing's workſhop, that I had been forced from the chair, that we had ſaid that we were aſſembled for petitioning a reform of parliament, and cloſed with prayer? Was that warrant which took me up then the ſame as before?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The warrant could not mention it, becauſe the petition was two days before the warrant was obtained; it could not mention that which did not take place for two days afterwards.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you recollect the Pannel being brought before you the 5th of December for examination?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did he at that time emit a declaration in your preſence?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He did.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did he do it voluntarily, and without compulſion?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was he ſober, and of ſound mind?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſubſcribe that declaration?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Look and ſee if that is it.—It is the ſame.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Is there any reference in that declaration to a motion?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was there a paper found in the ſecretary's poſſeſſion which appeared to be that motion?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you put any mark upon the paper ſo as to know it again?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; this is it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you recollect any other papers having been produced at that examination or afterwards?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There were no papers produced that day; the next day there were papers taken from a trunk of his, of which an inventory was made, which I identified.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was that trunk brought along with him?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was he aſked for the key of that trunk?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; and he declined giving it up.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was there any ſeal put upon it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not in my preſence; I underſtand there was.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When it was opened the following day, was any inventory made of the contents?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were there any papers other than thoſe claimed by the Pannel?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; papers belonging to Mr. Gerald.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were thoſe claimed by the Pannel ſeparated from thoſe claimed by Mr. Gerald?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; and an inventory was made of both, and they acquieſced in both.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And was it done in their preſence?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſubſcribe that inventory?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you likewiſe put any mark upon the articles which it contains?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you compare thoſe articles which have your ſuperſcription with the articles which are in the inventory?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; it was only thoſe that were relating to the buſineſs in hand that were put in the inventory. (Examines and compares them.) They are all marked by me.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you recollect why Mr. Margarot was liberated?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Upon finding bail.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What was the nature of the charge againſt him for which he was brought before you for examination?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: For ſeditious practices, as being a member of the meeting calling themſelves the Britiſh Convention of the Delegates of the Friends of the people.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you recollect to have gone in the execution of your duty to a wright's ſhop on the ſouth ſide of the town, the 6th of December, with a view of diſperſing this meeting?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Be ſo obliging to mention to the Court and Jury what paſſed when you ſo went to that meeting.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It was on Friday evening, the 6th of December, I went and attended the Lord Provoſt, with the magiſtrates of the city; a great number of people were aſſembled in a wright's ſhop, and I went immediately up to the table, where I ſaw ſome people whoſe faces I recognized; Mr. Skirving, Mr. Brown, Mr. Margarot, and ſeveral others; I aſked what the meeting was? I did not get a direct anſwer; I aſked if it was the Britiſh Convention? One of the members, and I think it was Mr. Margarot, ſaid that it was; I told him that I was Sheriff Subſtitute for the county, and that I came there to diſperſe that meeting, which was an illegal one, upon this ſome converſation took place; and I think Mr. Margarot was the man who ſpoke moſt on account of the Convention; he ſaid, they were met peaceably, that it was a legal Conſtitutional Meeting, and that they were then met for a petition to Parliament. I told him, that my reſolution had been taken before I came there; that I came with a determination to diſperſe that meeting; that no words were neceſſary, no argument that they could uſe could alter my determination: ſome more converſation took place. Mr. Margarot, finding I was determined upon it, ſaid that he would take the chair, with the approbation of the meeting, which was then empty; accordingly upon this, he was unanimouſly called to the chair: I think before he took the chair, he ſaid, the meeting would not diſperſe without force was uſed; I told him, I hoped it would be unneceſſary to uſe force, but if it was neceſſary, I ſhould certainly make uſe of it. He took the chair, and finding they would not diſperſe without ſome force, I took him by the arm, which he conſidered as force, and he came out of the chair; immediately upon his doing ſo, Mr. Gerald, another of the gentlemen preſent, took the chair; I told him I really thought that it was improper that another perſon ſhould do the ſame thing, if they were all to take the chair one after another; I hoped they would not think that neceſſary; however I took the ſame method of forcing Mr. Gerald from the chair that I did Mr. Margarot: Mr. Gerald then made an extempore prayer, and left the chair. Mr. Margarot, amongſt other things that he mentioned, ſaid, the meeting of the Convention had declared themſelves permament. I told him it might be ſo, but I was determined they ſhould not meet within the county where I had a juriſdiction. I think they called out for the gentlemen to diſperſe, and by degrees they diſperſed; and I ſaw the laſt perſon out, and ſaw the door locked, and took the key.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You ſaid you recognized ſeveral perſons; among others, the Pannel at the bar, and Mr. Gerald; how came you to recognize the Pannel particularly?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Becauſe he had been before me the night before, and had been examined upon the charge I have already mentioned.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You had granted bail?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.
sp.stage: (Harry Davidſon croſs examined by Mr. Margarot.)

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How are you ſure that the motion which you found in the poſſeſſion of Mr. Skirving is in my handwriting, as you have declared it to be?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not aſſert that it was your handwriting, at leaſt I did not mean to ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did I not give one uniform reaſon for declining to emit a declaration, for refuſing to give up the key of my trunk, and for aſſerting the right of the Convention to meet; did I not ſay, that the proceedings againſt them were illegal?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: You certainly did.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did I not aſk you, why you would interrupt us in our legal proceedings? and did you not anſwer me, that you acted according to order? Remember, Sir, that you are upon your oath.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot ſay that I recollect, whether I ſaid by order; as Sheriff ſubſtitute of the County, I acted by my own authority; I do not recollect the preciſe words I may have uſed, but I was certainly acting as Sheriff of the County.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What could induce you to think that a meeting like that was illegal?

sp.speaker: Lord Juſtice Clerk.
sp.p: That is not a proper queſtion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Margarot.
sp.p: It only hinges upon another. Did you ſee at the time of your entrance there, any confuſion, riot, or diſorder?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you on the contrary, perceive the buſineſs of the evening carried on with regularity?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There was but little buſineſs going on after I came in, Mr. Gerald was upon his legs ſpeaking, and I certainly interrupted him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was prayer called for?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It was, I do not know whether it was not you that ſaid it was not uſual that the meeting ſhould depart without prayer; and I believe I gave conſent that prayer ſhould be made.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: O, you did conſent to that? Do you recollect the ſubject of the debate?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think you, or ſome other perſon, put into my hand a ſmall piece of paper, upon which was wrote a petition to Parliament, which you ſaid was the ſubject of the—

sp.speaker: Mr. Margarot.
sp.p: Of the order of the day.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That the purpoſe of their meeting was to petition Parliament.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I hope the order of the day is not an offence, becauſe I believe it is made uſe of ſometimes in the Houſe of Commons.

sp.speaker: Counſel for the Crown.
sp.p:
The witneſs has ſpoke of the motion referred to in the declaration. Was there any paper ſound in
Mr. Skirving's poſſeſſion, which was entitled Minutes of the Convention.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There were a number of things found in Mr. Skirving's poſſeſſion; amongſt which, a ſcroll of the Minutes of the Convention.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Should you know it again?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Look at that and ſee if that is it?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Mr. Margarot.
sp.p: How are you certain that theſe are the minutes of the Britiſh Convention.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I can only ſay, that theſe are papers which were found in Mr. Skirving's poſſeſſion, and they were acknowledged to be ſo by various people, who were examined before me; that is the only reaſon I have: I did not ſee them in the Convention.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: There is another queſtion which I hope your Lordſhips will not think improper. In your office as Sheriff, have you to the beſt of your judgment acted according to the laws of your country, or have you acted by ſuperior orders?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I certainly would execute no orders, unleſs I was certain they were according to the laws of my country.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Am I to infer from hence, that you received orders?

sp.speaker: Lord Juſtice Clerk.
sp.p: It is not a proper ſubject of evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Margarot.
sp.p: I put myſelf under your correction at the time I ſtarted the queſtion; however, it may not be amiſs that the queſtion was ſtarted, though it is not anſwered.
Joſeph Mack ſworn.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you recollect being preſent when Mr. Skirving, the late Secretary of the Convention of the Friends of the People, was brought before the ſheriff for examination?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were there certain bags of papers brought along with him for inſpection?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you preſent when thoſe bags were opened?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was, when they were put into the inventory, which was very ſoon after or immediately after they were opened.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was Skirving preſent?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you recollect among other papers found in this bag, one being found, entitled the Scroll of the Minutes of the Convention?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was it in your hand, that you had an opportunity of obſerving it at that time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I both ſaw it then, and at Mr. Skirving's houſe; they were carried in a bag from his houſe to the ſheriff clerk's office, and there entered into an inventory—that is the paper.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And you now recognize it as the ſame?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: (Looks over it) Yes, it is the ſame.
sp.stage: Joſeph Mack croſs examined by Mr. Margarot.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You act as notary, do you not?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I do not

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Or as clerk to the ſheriff?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, writing clerk to the ſheriff.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear me proteſt againſt the illegality of all the proceedings which had taken place?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: You offered to make a proteſt, but it was refuſed to you.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You are certain that I offered to make one?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: A written one?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not recollect whether it was written or not: I think it is probable it was, but I cannot ſay—I was not a notary.

sp.speaker: Mr. Margarot.
sp.p: I have objections to that witneſs, on account of certain expreſſions of his, and I have a witneſs now attending to prove thoſe words. I don't know whether that witneſs ſhould be brought in at preſent to prove this, or whether it ſhould be kept back till the witneſſes for the proſecution are gone through.

sp.speaker: Lord Juſtice Clerk.
sp.p: What do you propoſe to prove?

sp.speaker: Mr. Margarot.
sp.p: That he conſidered himſelf as my enemy; theſe are nearly the words, I look upon myſelf to be your enemy; or ſomething to that effect.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Can you condeſcend upon any reaſon, why he ſhould have any enmity to you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Margarot.
sp.p: I have not the ſkill of other people; I cannot dive into mens hearts; I find him a very officious time-ſerving man.

sp.speaker: Lord Juſtice Clerk.
sp.p: He muſt anſwer that queſtion upon oath, whether he has any malice or ill will.
(Sworn.)

sp.speaker: Lord Juſtice Clerk.
sp.p: Look upon the pannel at the bar; have you any malice or ill-will againſt that perſon?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: None at all.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ever ſay that you were his enemy?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Lord Juſtice Clerk.
sp.p: You may aſk him the queſtion again, Mr. Margarot.

sp.speaker: Mr. Margarot.
sp.p: I would wiſh to have my witneſs produced in court; it is not my aſking him the queſtion merely, Do you not recollect ſaying one day that you conſidered yourſelf as my enemy?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Lord Abercrombie.
sp.p: The court have uniformly laid this down as a rule, that no general charge of a witneſs making uſe of an expreſſion of that nature ſhall be ſufficient to invalidate his teſtimony, and for this reaſon, that it would put it in the power of cry witneſs whatever, if he wiſhed to favour the pannel, to diſqualify himſelf by uttering ſome vague expreſſion of ill-will.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſkgrove.
sp.p: What are you?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: A meſſenger.

sp.speaker: Lord Advocate.
sp.p: Did you execute a warrant againſt the pannel?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Advocate.
sp.p: And againſt any body elſe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; Mr. Gerald.
Q Where was you informed theſe perſons reſided?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: At the Black Bull.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were you to take into your cuſtody any papers that you found?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: At what time in the morning was it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: To the beſt of my knowledge about ſeven o'clock.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Tell the court and jury what paſſed.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I aſked for ſuch gentlemen, I aſked for their rooms; the waiter declined ſhewing me, but told me the number of their rooms; I went into the room where Mr. Gerald and Mr. Margarot were; they were each in ſeparate beds in the ſame room.
Q Did you tell them you had a warrant againſt them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; then I went to Mr. Sinclair's room, and locked up all Mr. Margarot's papers, and Mr. Gerald's and Mr. Sinclair's alſo; Mr. Margarot ſaid he would put his papers into a little trunk, which I did not object to.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did he accordingly do ſo?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He aſked Mr. Gerald if he would put his in, upon which he agreed to it, and the papers were put in; and when I was away and came back for them, he ſaid he would not give them me; I ſaid I would take them; he ſaid I might take them at my peril, and I ſaid I ſhould not make any ſcruple about it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the key remain in his poſſeſſion after the paper was taken away?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, the trunk was locked and he kept the key.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you take the trunk and him with you to the ſheriff's?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, and Mr. Gerald.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you preſent when the trunk was opened and the contents examined?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the pannel agree to open the trunk himſelf, or was it opened?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The next day when he was before the ſheriff, he held the key in his hand; he ſaid he would not give it up, but we might take it from him; upon which the ſheriff ſubſtitute deſired me to take it from him, which I did; the trunk was then opened and inſpected.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were thoſe belonging to the pannel diſtinguiſhed from thoſe belonging to Mr. Gerald?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Each of them claimed ſeparately what belonged to himſelf.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was there any inventory made of thoſe papers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you put any mark upon thoſe papers? —A. I did.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Look at thoſe papers deliberately, and ſee if they are the ſame?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: (Examines and compares them with the inventory.) Yes, they are the ſame; they have my initial.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When you went to the Black Bull had you any aſſiſtants with you?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, John M'Donald and Neil M'Glaſhan were both in the room along with me.
sp.stage: James Lyon croſs examined by Mr. Margarot.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You found us in bed?—A. Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did we ſhow any diſpoſition of reſiſtance, or rather teſtify the greateſt alacrity to go with you?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: You ſhewed no diſpoſition to make any reſiſtance; you did not refuſe to come along with us.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did we make you wait long in dreſſing?—A. No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ſhew us the warrants?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, nor you did aſk it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did we never aſk you to ſee the warrant?—A. No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did you find the papers in the room?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I found ſome upon the top of the drawers' head, ſome in the drawers, and ſome out in a trunk.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were the drawers locked?—A. No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was the door of the room locked?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I knocked at the door, and you deſired me to come in, and of courſe I opened the door.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were the papers in a ſtate of arrangement when you took them off the drawers, and out of the drawers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, by no means.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were they not rather confuſed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; they were a little confuſed.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were there ſome in one place, and others in others?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, ſome I got out of the trunk, and ſome in the drawers, and ſome off the drawers.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were there papers in more than one drawer?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I believe there were; I cannot ſay.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: But the drawers were not locked?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I believe not; at leaſt I broke none of them open.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you go along with Mr. Lyon, the meſſenger, to aſſiſt him to execute a warrant againſt the Pannel at the bar, on the 5th December laſt?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did you go?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: To the Black Bull, at the head of Leith Walk.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Tell us, as far as you recollect, what paſſed upon that occaſion?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
I went into the houſe, and ſtood there till the door was opened; Mr. Lyon went in; he went up the ſtair, and this gentleman and another were in the bed-room, but had not got their clothes on, and we ſtood at the door till they were ready;
and Mr. Lyon took what papers he could find, and they were put into a trunk; the trunk was locked, and he put the key in his pocket, and there was a coach at the door; and I took down the trunk, and put in the chaiſe, and he came along with us, and I got at the back of the chaiſe, and went to the Sheriff Clerk's Office, and left the trunk at the office.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You have mentioned what paſſed in the room, and the manner in which the papers were put in the trunk; now, did the Pannel himſelf put any of the papers in?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, he was helping.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did Mr. Gerald likewiſe aſſiſt to put the papers in the trunk?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; Mr. Gerald's papers were put in firſt, and then Mr. Margarot's, and then the trunk was locked and carried to the Sheriff Clerk's Office.
sp.stage: John Macdonald, croſs examined by Mr. Margarot.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Could you at that time diſcriminate which were my papers and which were thoſe of Mr. Gerald?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I can neither tell which were yours, nor which were his; but, it is my opinion, your's were put in firſt.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were the drawers locked?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You did not ſee a key in thoſe drawers?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was the room door locked?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, it was open when I came in; you was apprehended, I dare ſay, before I came in.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were the papers put into the trunk tied up in parcels or looſely?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Some were tied up, and ſome were looſe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did we tie up any of them before you

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not ſee any ſtring tied on them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who took them out of the drawers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Mr. Lyon took them out.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you recollect the reaſon why Mr. Lyon would not ſhew me the warrant?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: You did not inſiſt upon ſhewing it much.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did he ſhew it? and remember you are upon your oath.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot recollect.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You well recollect that I aſked him to produce it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And you are not certain that he did ſhew it?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: But you perfectly recollect that I aſked him to ſhew it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Juſtice Clerk.
sp.p: Have you any objection to this witneſs?

sp.speaker: Mr. Margarot.
sp.p: No, my Lord, he looks honeſt. (Sworn).

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are you a member of any of the Societies of Friends of the People?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you a Delegate from that ſociety to the Britiſh Convention?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I was a member of both.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you attend regularly their meeting?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: My buſineſs did not allow me a regular attendance, but I attended as often as I could.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you recollect, during your attendance at thoſe meetings, whether there was any ſubdiviſion, any ſmaller meetings that the Convention was divided into?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What were they called?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The firſt name they got, was Diviſions; but they were afterwards called Sections.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What terms did the members of the Convention generally addreſs each other by?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The terms were different; but the general term was, Citizen.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you recollect that you had different Committees appointed in that Convention for the forwarding of buſineſs?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't recollect ſeveral Committees.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: But ſome?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I have heard ſome mentioned.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And what were they called?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That that I recollect moſt, at preſent, was the Committee of Union.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ever hear of a Committee of Secrecy?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: A Convention of Emergency?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't recollect the hearing of that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you recollect hearing the term organization mentioned? —

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't remember.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Had you primary aſſemblies to refer to?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot ſay.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How were your meetings called?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It was generally called the Britiſh Convention.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: But when you met on a particular night, and talked about it the next day, what name did you give it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The Britiſh Convention.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ever uſe the name of ſittings?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, frequently.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You ſay you attended as often as your buſineſs permitted?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Have you had occaſion to ſee the pannel there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, frequently.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee him act as Preſes or Chairman at theſe meetings?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ever hear him move any reſolutions at theſe meetings, of any kind?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I have very frequently heard Mr. Margarot ſpeak; but unleſs ſome particular reſolution be mentioned, I cannot ſay.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you recollect at any time, any motion or propoſal for a Committee of Union?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No; I was not preſent then.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you recollect his having delivered a ſpeech, at any of the meetings you have attended, that had any relation to a Convention Bill?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't recollect.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: With any reference to ſuch a bill as had paſſed in Ireland?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No:

sp.speaker: Mr. Solicitor General.
sp.p: Do you remember a motion being made by Mr. Calendar?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you remember any thing what it was about?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I remember one of the motions, about the people meeting in defence of their liberties, in caſe of any bill being brought into Parliament, ſimilar to a Convention Bill in Ireland againſt the Conſtitution of the country.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What did Mr. Calendar propoſe that your Convention ſhould do in that caſe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I recollect a motion of that import being introduced, and that Mr. Calendar acknowledged the motion as his; but as to any thing relative to that motion, I do not know.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you preſent when the motion was made?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There was a rule in the Convention, that no motion ſhould be diſcuſſed the ſame night on which it was made; I was preſent when it was brought in by Mr. Calendar.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What was it that Mr. Calendar propoſed ſhould be done in caſe ſuch a bill ſhould be brought into the Britiſh Parliament?

sp.speaker: Mr. Margarot.
sp.p: I object to that queſtion, as it reſpects Mr. Calendar, and not me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Solicitor General.
sp.p: It is charged in the indictment againſt this very pannel; and, therefore, I will repeat the queſtion. What was it that Mr. Calendar propoſed ſhould be done, in caſe it ſhould be brought into the Britiſh Parliament?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That the people ſhould meet to aſſert their right, ſo far as I recollect.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was there any debate upon it that night?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is a rule that there ſhall be no debate when a queſtion is propoſed.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you preſent when it was diſcuſſed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not when it was diſcuſſed in that ſhape in which Mr. Callendar introduced it; but I was when it was amended: ſo far as I recollect, the ſpirit of Mr. Calendar's motion was retained; but it was very much extended: there was a propoſal of what, in certain events, ſhould take place. I don't clearly remember the circumſtances about it; but it was a motion for a Secret Committee, in caſe thoſe events ſhould take place.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was it propoſed that the Convention ſhould aſſemble in certain events?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, it was, that they ſhould meet in a certain place, in certain events.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Now, be ſo good as tell us what thoſe events were, as far as you remember them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The one already named, was that of a bill being brought into Parliament ſimilar to the Convention Bill in Ireland; as to the other, I cannot remember.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was any thing ſaid about the ſuſpenſion of the Habeas Corpus Act?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think there was.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was there any thing ſaid about the repeal of the Scotch Act, 1701, of wrongous impriſonment?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't recollect that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was any thing ſaid in caſe of an invaſion of foreign troops?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think I remember that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was any place fixed upon for the meetings? how was that determined upon?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There was a motion that a place ſhould be fixed upon by a Secret Committee; they were to find out a way of letting the Delegates know of it.
Q Was it not to be publiſhed?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was it to be told them immediately, or only told them when that emergency ſhould happen?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There was a mention of a ſealed letter to be given to each Delegate.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who made this motion with reſpect to the place of meeting?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot recollect.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Read that paper.

"Citizen Margarot propoſed the following motion: That a Secret Committee of three, with the Secretary, be appointed to determine the place where ſuch Convention of Emergency ſhall meet; and ſuch place ſhall remain a ſecret with them, and with the Secretary of this Convention; and, that the Delegates ſhall, at the breaking up of the preſent ſeſſion, be entruſted with a ſealed letter, containing the name of the place of meeting. This letter ſhall be delivered unopened to their conſtituents; the receipt of which ſhall be acknowledged by a letter to the Secretary, preſerved in the ſame ſtate, until the period ſhall arive at which it ſhall be deemed neceſſary for the Delegates to ſet off. This motion was ſeconded by Citizen Moffat."

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Is that the motion?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: To the beſt of my recollection there was a motion of a ſimilar import to that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know who were the Members of this Secret Committee?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I recollect ſome of them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was Mr. Margarot one of them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: To the beſt of my recollection, he was one of them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you remember Mr. Margarot making any ſpeech to the Convention before he had made his motion?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you remember his ſaying any thing at all about its being a tocſin?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You remember that the caſe of the Convention Bill was one of the caſes of emergency?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And of the ſuſpenſion of the Habeas Corpus Act?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I heard that mentioned.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You alſo recollect ſomething about an invaſion being mentioned?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think I do.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any propoſal during the time you attended this meeting, that this Convention ſhould act in caſe they ſhould be diſperſed?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who made that motion?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not recollect at preſent.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you think Mr. Margarot made a motion of that kind?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It runs in my mind that he did; but I cannot ſwear that it was him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear Mr. Margarot make any ſpeech that had a reference to that caſe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think I recollect ſomething of Mr. Margarot ſpeaking as to the propriety of ſuch a thing.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are you ſure?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot be particular; but there is a conceit in my mind that he did.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you remember Mr. Sinclair making a motion of that kind?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think I do.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you remember any thing particular about the paſſing of that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: So far as my recollection ſerves me, we were pretty unanimous.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you recollect all the Convention ſtanding up at the time they paſſed it?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; I think I do.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did it contain any particular expreſſions of their declaring before God and the world that they would do ſo and ſo? Do you recollect that that made a part of the motion?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Certainly theſe words were mentioned, but I am not certain whether it was the decided reſolution of the Convention or not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you remember whether this motion, or the reſolution of the Convention, bore any thing that they declared before God and the world that we ſhould follow the wholeſome example of former times?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot ſay; I don't remember it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did it ſay any thing about paying no attention to a Convention Bill if it ſhould be paſſed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
I think there was a mention of ſomething ſimilar to this, but whether it was made a part of the final reſolution of the
Committee, I cannot tell: there was a great deal of looſe expreſſions made uſe of.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any thing ſaid in the Convention about burning that reſolution of Sinclair's?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I heard nothing of that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any thing ſaid about burning any of the other motions?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't recollect; they ſeemed, to be confident of what they were doing, and were not acting, under the apprehenſion of fear.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was there any thing ſaid about deſtroying or not inſerting it in the minutes?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't recollect.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: At the time this Secret Committee was appointed, was there any oppoſition made to it?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't recollect.
sp.stage: Thomas Coburn croſs examined by Mr. Margarot.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: It ſeems you are a member of the Britiſh Convention?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is your profeſſion?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: My profeſſion is partly a manufacturer in the weaving line, and partly a merchant.
Q Do you pay any taxes?—I do.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you find theſe taxes heavy?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I have very often thought them very heavy.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You are a member of the Friends of the People?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What was your reaſon for joining the Friends of the People?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The reaſon was, a thorough conviction of the neceſſity of a Reform in the Britiſh Houſe of Commons.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What was your reaſon of accepting the office of delegate in the Britiſh Convention?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: It was to help forward that great and grand object that ſo forcibly ſtruck my mind.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you mean to help it forward by legal means or force of arms?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Force of arms was never mentioned in the Convention, and it is the laſt thing that I ſhould wiſh, to ſee a drop of blood ſpilt in the cauſe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: In the Britiſh Convention did you ever ſee any tendency to have recourſe to open force?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It was diametrically oppoſite to my views to have the leaſt recourſe to open force, nor was it the ſubject of diſcuſſion in the Convention.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Have you heard of a committee of Union?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What was to be the purport of that Committee of Union?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
So far as I recollect, the deſign of that Committee was to draw up regulations, by which the people of England and Scotland,
of the ſame ſentiments, might join in their endeavours to obtain that object.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You have heard of a Convention of Secrecy likewiſe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Of a Committee of Secrecy I have.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Have you ever ſeen it cuſtomary in any Clubs, if you ever belonged to any, that there ſhould be a certain degree of truſt repoſed in a ſmall number of confidential men, who ſhould form a Committee and retain ſome ſecrets to themſelves, not to be divulged to the world? Have you ever witneſſed any ſuch thing, or does it ſtrike you as an unprecedented thing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: So far from ſtriking me as an unprecedented thing, that it ſtrikes me upon many occaſions as a neceſſary thing, prudentially to keep ſecrets of every ſociety when it is neceſſary for their intereſt.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Have you ever heard of a Committee of Organization in the Convention?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I think I have.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What was the drift of that Committee of Organization?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: What I conceive to be the direct deſign of the Committee was to form rules, by which the Convention might regulate themſelves in their preſent and in their ſubſequent meetings, if they ſhould ſee occaſion for any.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you think that the Committee of Organization did not likewiſe refer to the internal regulation of the Convention?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: As I meant to expreſs in my laſt anſwer, I conſidered the committee of Organization to refer chiefly to the internal affairs of the Convention, and with reſpect to future Conventions, if there ſhould be ſuch.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: It ſeems that you have heard that meetings of the Convention were at times called ſittings; do you imagine that that expreſſion was adopted as borrowed from a neighbouring country, or that is was an expreſſion which followed of courſe, and to which we are thoroughly accuſtomed in the Engliſh language?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: However the reading of newſpapers might lead us to make uſe of terms, I cannot ſay; but it was certainly a word that it was very natural to make uſe of.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You have ſeen me act as Preſes?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: That word is Latin, is it not?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I am very little acquainted with Latin▪ I meant Preſident.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You are ſufficiently acquainted with it to know that at preſent Rome is the ſeat of the Pope, are you not?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: We have no doubt of that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Conſequently if there is any criminality in adopting a French word, do you think there is not an equal criminality in uſing a Latin one▪

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Theſe things appeared to me to be ſo trifling, that I did not think it worth my while to make any objection to them: ſome were of French origin, and ſome of Britiſh, and ſome of Latin; but I did not think it worth while to make any objection to it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You have heard of a motion propoſed by Mr. Callender; you were preſent when it was originally moved, that the people ſhould meet to aſſert their rights in the Convention?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Aſſert their rights, were the words, to the beſt of my recollection.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What do you underſtand by a Convention?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: What I underſtand by a Convention is a meeting of men for any purpoſe that they propoſe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are the men who meet in Convention ſuppoſed to be delegated by a larger body of men?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot pretend a particular diſquiſition of theſe points, but it ſtrikes me ſo.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: By the word Convention, and meeting in Convention, did you underſtand a peaceable aſſembly of men aſſembled to deliberate, or did you underſtand by it, an aſſembly of men going to adopt violent meaſures, and to carry them into execution themſelves?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: What I underſtand by Convention was, that they met with a ſincere and hearty deſign to promote the good of the country, by a thorough reform in the Britiſh Houſe of Commons, and that they meant to do this by peaceable means.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you imagine there are ſufficient abuſes at preſent in the legiſlature of this kingdom, to legalize our attempting to addreſs them by petition, or any form that might be legal and conſtitutional?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I have already ſaid that I am deeply impreſſed with the idea of the neceſſity of it: I ſee the moſt glaring abuſes in it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you imagine that if a Convention Bill was to be paſſed, or was even to be brought into the Houſe of Commons, that it would not ſhew a diſpoſition in the Houſe of Commons to extend their privileges, and to encroach upon our rights?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Such a Bill has always ſtruck me as ſapping the very foundations of Civil Liberty; and, indeed going beyond the power of the legiſlators themſelves, to deprive the people of their natural rights.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You ſay it is your opinion that there are already ſufficient grounds for the good people of this country to demand a Reform in Parliament; do you think thoſe grounds would not be increaſed by two ſuch events as the bringing in of a Convention Bill, or a motion for ſuſpending the Habeas Corpus act, which is one of the greateſt privileges a ſubject of Britain enjoys, or the Bill for preventing wrongous impriſonment; do you think that would not make a very conſiderable addition to our complaints?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I am ſatisfied in my own mind, that it would increaſe the grievances of the people, and be like a grave ſtone to their liberties.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: In what light did you look upon the members of the Britiſh Convention? Did you look upon them as a turbulent ſet of vagabonds, or did you look upon them as a body of men delegated by ſome of their fellow ſubjects for a certain purpoſe, and that theſe men ſo delegated were induſtrious, peaceable, creditable men?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Their deſign, I have to reaſon no call in queſtion, was the good of their country: as to characters, there is always a mixture in all aſſemblies; but I believe, taking the whole together, there was a great degree of reſpectability with reſpect to characters.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Then they did not appear to you to come under the deſcription of ſwine, rabble, or wretches?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: As the friends of their country, I believe not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When is the propereſt time for men to aſſemble and deliberate? It in time of danger, or proſperity? It appears that the Convention was to aſſemble in this manner, in the moment that an invaſion of foreign troops ſhould take place in Great Britain. Do you conceive that to be a time of danger, and calling for the attention of all Britons throughout the iſland; or do you think it a time for them to ſit idle and ſuffer themſelves to be enſlaved by a foreign power?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think it is high time that a Reform had taken place, as it ought to have done long ſince.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When you have any thing that intereſts you very much, do you publiſh it all through your houſe, and different parts of your family, or ſometimes keep a ſecret to yourſelf in your private affairs?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, no doubt; and every perſon endued with any degree of prudence will find occaſion to keep their ſecrets.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: If you had a particular piece of buſineſs to do, and that you was apprehenſive that a ſuperior power, inimical to your deſign and to your welfare, would prevent you from doing that particular buſineſs at ſuch a place, would you inform that inimical power where you was to meet to do that buſineſs?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ſhould certainly do every thing in my power, from common prudence, to keep it from him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When you ſend a letter by the poſt to a friend do you ever attach any degree of criminality to ſealing that letter till he gets into the country, eſpecially if you wiſh the contents not to be known to him till a certain period?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Can you diſcover any thing of a ſeditious nature in a Convention ſtanding up to paſs a reſolution?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p:
I find here ſomething which I don't know, whether it is thoroughly aſſented to by you, that there was a declaration before God and the world, that they would follow the wholeſome
example of their forefathers; what is the characteriſtic of Britons?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That they are ſtrongly attached to the cauſe of liberty.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How came we by the Revolution? was it by any exertion of our forefathers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It no doubt was.
Q How came we by the Magna Charta?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: So far as I underſtand the ſubject, it was entirely by the ſame means.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did your forefathers do wrong in ſo exerting themſelves?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: My opinion is that they did not do enough.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you think it impoſſible for a Houſe of Commons to do an unconſtitutional act?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There has been many things done in the Houſe of Commons which I ſincerely regret.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: We had originally Parliaments, or ſome time back, Parliaments of three years; now by an Act of Parliament they are lengthened to ſeven years; ſuppoſe another Act ſhould make them during life, and a third Act ſhould make them hereditary, do you imagine that would be an unconſtitutional act?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It has always ſtruck me as a thing beyond their power to alter or deſtroy the fundamental rights of the people, or any thing that would extend their own power.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you imagine that the power originates with the people?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do ſo.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you imagine it to be either in the Bill of Rights, or the claim of rights, expreſſed, that the people ſhould be at liberty to meet to communicate to each other their grievances, and plan methods for obtaining redreſs?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I have often wiſhed to ſee the Bill of Rights, the Habeas Corpus Act, and all thoſe things; but I have never had it in my power; but in my opinion, the object of all government is the good of the people, and that the liberties of the people ought to be carefully guarded by them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: It appears by what has paſſed here, that the Convention had ſome notion of a God: did they ever pray in their meetings?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They did.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee any diſorderly behaviour there? were they riotous or tumultuous?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Conſidering their numbers, they were free of that beyond many meetings that I have ſeen of the ſame number: I ſaw no riotous meetings: there were ſometimes diſputes, but no riots.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: As to the burning of the motion, you ſaid they were not acting under the apprehenſion of fear: did you ſuppoſe they could juſtify their proceedings?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I always conſidered, that in the Convention the Members that had occaſion to ſpeak, always ſpoke freely, believing that they had nothing eſſentially ſecret to keep to themſelves, but that their great object was the good of their country.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ever diſcover in the Convention or in the members of it, either in or out of the Convention, any propenſity to ſedition, treaſon, or rebellion?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I have always ſaid, that as far as I could diſcover the deſign of the Convention, it was to obtain a thorough Reform in the Britiſh Houſe of Commons, by peaceable and legal means.

sp.speaker: Mr. Alexander Aitcheſon
sp.p: ſworn.

sp.speaker: Lord Henderland.
sp.p: Have you any malice or ill-will againſt the pannel at the bar?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is impoſſible I ſhould, my Lord: on the contrary, I eſteem him a ſecond Sydney.—I am very much obliged to the public proſecutor, on account of my family, otherwiſe, I would much ſooner appear here as the pannel at your Lordſhips' bar, than as a witneſs.

sp.speaker: Counſel for the Crown.
sp.p: Were you a Member of the Britiſh Convention?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; of all the three Conventions I had the honour to be a Delegate from the Canongate Society; the Delegates, conſidering themſelves as Delegates for ſix months, adjourned their meeting; but upon account of the coming down of the Engliſh Delegates, they reſumed it again.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: That was in November laſt.—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who were the Engliſh Delegates?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There were four or five of them; there was Citizen Margarot, Citizen Sinclair, Citizen Gerald from London, and Citizen Brown from Sheffield.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Now did you act as ſecretary or aſſiſtant ſecretary?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; aſſiſtant ſecretary.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were there a ſcroll of minutes drawn up?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Look at that, and ſee if any part of it is your hand-writing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; a very great part of it; but there were ſome others who wrote.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who were they?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: George Roſs, and afterwards the Convention appointed three aſſiſtants daily.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who is George Roſs?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Clerk in the Gazetteer Office.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: This ſcroll of minutes, did they contain, to far as you could judge, a fair and diſtinct account of what happened in the Convention?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
To the beſt of my knowledge and belief they did; I ſhould have been guilty of palming falſhood upon the public and
the Convention if they did not: but there may have been miſtakes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were they corrected the day after they were made out?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: By no means: they were poſtponed till a future day, till a committee ſhould be appointed to reviſe them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was Mr. Margarot preſent at theſe meetings commonly?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: As far as I obſerved he was a regular attendant.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was he ſometimes Chairman at the meetings?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Once he certainly was.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Look at that: whoſe hand-writing is it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is mine (reads it). Citizen Margarot moved that a Committtee be appointed to conſider of the means, and draw up the outlines of a proper plan for a general union between the two nations, as before propoſed.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did Mr. Margarot make that motion?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He certainly did, or I ſhould not have minuted it down: a ſimple fact like that I cannot be miſtaken in; but in a ſpeech, viva voce, I might have made a miſtake (reads it again); and give me leave to add, I expected from Mr. Margarot's abilities and the ſpirit of the times, a more perfect ſyſtem than was made up by a ſycophant faction in the reign of queen Anne.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Look at that.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: (Reads.) Citizen A. Callendar moved, That in caſe the Miniſter bring into the Commons' Houſe a motion for a Convention Bill, it ſhall be noticed immediately to the Delegates. The words ſhall be noticed immediately to the Delegates, are in my hand-writing.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you remember any diſcuſſion in the Convention upon that motion; particularly, did Mr. Margarot ſpeak upon the occaſion?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Indeed my memory is ſo treacherous that I cannot recollect any thing, eſpecially when I am taking notes: if I don't write at all, I remember tolerably well the chief facts, but if I do write, I recollect nothing.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was there any thing ſaid about that event being a tocſin to the friends of liberty?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I never heard the word tocſin mentioned in the Convention.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you remember any amendment or alteration upon Mr. Callendar's motion, or if it gave riſe to any other motion in the Convention?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Such things may have happened, but I cannot recollect.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know of a motion being-made by Mr. Sinclair in conſequence of, and following up Mr. Callendar's motion?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was abſent a variety of nights, when I wiſhed to be preſent, but particular buſineſs kept me away.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: But did you hear Mr. Margarot make any motion in conſequence of Mr. Callendar's?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: 'Tis impoſſible that I can ſay.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did Mr. Sinclair make any motion about the Convention meeting on certain events?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; there was a motion made, at leaſt I underſtood ſo. I came in one evening pretty late, and Mr. Sinclair, or ſome perſon, had made a motion, and as ſoon as I had taken my ſeat, Mr. Sinclair made a motion, that ſomething that had paſſed before ſhould be burned, and I was ſurpriſed, and got up and oppoſed it, and was ſeconded—upon the ground, that as every thing we had done before was open to the public, we ſhould do nothing ſecret, and therefore the motion was not carried.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did that motion relate to the Delegates' meeting?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was ſurpriſed and alarmed at any thing being ſecret; but when I underſtood that nothing more was meant by it than merely concealing the place where they were to meet, I thought there was nothing at all in it.

sp.speaker: Lord Juſtice Clerk.
sp.p: Did you hear any thing of a Committee of Secrecy?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I enquired next day, and was told the nature of it, that it was merely to conceal the intended place of meeting, in caſe of oppoſition, and in caſe of neceſſity.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any thing about the Convention of Emergency at all in the meeting?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; at the ſections and among our friends.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Read that.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: (Reads from the minutes.) Citizen Margarot read and propoſed the following motion: That a Secret Committee of three, and the Secretary, be appointed to determine the place where ſuch Convention of Emergency ſhall meet; and ſuch place ſhall remain a ſecret with them and the Secretary of this Convention, and that each Delegate ſhall, at the breaking up of the preſent ſeſſion, be entruſted with a ſealed letter, containing the name of the place of the meeting; this letter ſhall be delivered unopened to his conſtituents, the receipt of which ſhall be acknowledged by a letter to the Secretary, preſerved in the ſame ſtate, until the period ſhall arrive at which it ſhall be deemed neceſſary for the Delegates to ſet off; this motion was ſeconded by Citizen Moffat: the greater part of that is my own hand-writing.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You ſee mention is there made of a Convention of Emergency: now I want to know, as far as you recollect, the caſes in which they were to meet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: As far as I recollect, they were to meet in caſe a motion was made in Parliament to bring in a bill ſimilar to that paſſed in Ireland, to prevent our having any meetings.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was one of the caſes the ſuſpenſion of the Habeas Corpus Act?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't recollect.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was the caſe of an invaſion of foreign troops mentioned?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you recollect any other caſe of Emergency in which the Convention were to meet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't recollect any other.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was there another caſe, if any attempt ſhould be made to diſperſe the Convention? was that a caſe in which they were to meet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot ſay that I recollect that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you in the Convention the evening before the apprehenſion of Mr. Margarot and Skirving, and the other perſons?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I might, very poſſibly; but I don't recollect I was preſent that evening after they had been apprehended in the morning.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: But do you recollect whether you was in the Convention the preceding evening?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot charge my memory with it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Look at that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The whole of that is written by another perſon (reads from the Minutes). Citizen Margarot begs leave to bring in a motion, to the effect, that the moment of any illegal diſperſion of the preſent Convention ſhall be conſidered as a ſummons to the Delegates to repair to the place of meeting appointed for the Convention of Emergency by the Secret Committee; that the Secret Committee is inſtructed to proceed, without delay, to fix the place of meeting; and that the ſame motion be conſidered next evening; which was accordingly granted. My Lords, I obſerve, from the whole of this being written by another perſon, that I was not preſent at all that evening.

sp.speaker: Lord Advocate.
sp.p: Look at the firſt of theſe papers, Number 3. of the general inventory, and tell me if you ever ſaw it before?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: (Reads from the Minutes a motion for a union between the two kingdoms, to demand the reſtoration of their rights.) I think it is a moſt excellent motion, my Lord, and am very ſorry it was not followed up.

sp.speaker: Lord Advocate.
sp.p: I did not aſk you for your opinion, Sir.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: My Lords, I beg to ſay, this perſecution, and all of them, are for opinions; and I muſt, before God, in juſtice to my country, declare, that it is for opinions as well as facts.
Gentlemen of the Jury, 'Tis a proſecution for opinions.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Look at that paper which has your mark upon it.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It has, but it is not my writing.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did you receive it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: From the Convention; I remember reading it from the beginning to the end.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who is James Gartley?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He was Delegate from Glaſgow.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Is it your hand-writing upon the back of it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; it is.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Had you an opportunity of ſeeing the newſpapers in which the proceedings of the Convention were publiſhed to the world?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I had an opportunity; but was ſo extremely hurried at that time with my own buſineſs, and that of the Convention, that I could not read them, but laid them by to be a treaſure of entertainment at ſome future time; for four weeks, at that time, I did not read a ſingle article in the Gazetteer.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Have you read them ſince?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Only in the Sheriff Clerk's Chamber; and that ſeemed to contain a very accurate account.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And correſponded with the Minutes you yourſelf had taken?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.
sp.stage: Alexander Aitcheſon croſs examined by Mr. Margarot.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You was a member of the Britiſh Convention?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you, prior to that, a Member of the Friends of the People?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, long prior.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What was your motive for aſſociating with the Friends of the People?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The public good, which I hope I will always have at heart.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What do you underſtand by the public good.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I underſtand, by the public good, that grievances ſhould be redreſſed, and every man made as happy as poſſible.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Had you any ſpecific plan?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, we had juſt two objects; theſe two objects were, a ſhorter duration of Parliaments, and a more frequent election of Repreſentatives; becauſe we conſidered the length of parliaments, and the ſlow return of elections, to be the two great and fundamental cauſes of all the grievances which the nation labours under.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What ſort of men were theſe with whom you aſſociated, the Friends of the People? I don't particularly mean what claſs, high or low, rich or poor; but what morals, what temper, what behaviour; in ſhort, what opinion do you form of them in general?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I conſidered them to be a good, moral, reſpectable ſet of people; not reſpectable in point of riches, but in that reſpect which will be looked at by the all-ſeeing-eye of the Almighty; reſpectable in point of morals.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did they ever ſhew any diſpoſition to treaſon, ſedition, or felony?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not that I ever ſaw.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you delegated by a Society of the Friends of the People to the Convention?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was ſome time.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the other Members of the Convention repreſent a number of men from here?—A Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did it appear to you, that the Convention adhered to the ſpirit of reform which was ſet on foot by the Friends of the People?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They certainly did, to the beſt of my ideas; and even when they followed up the primary idea of ſhorter duration of Parliaments, and more frequent elections, and adopted the idea of univerſal ſuffrage and annual Parliaments, they went certainly no further than the Duke of Richmond and Mr. Pitt had gone before.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You muſt take care not to mention the word primary, becauſe it may inculpate me further; for that is one word that is charged againſt me.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I conſider all words in our Dictionary lawful to be uſed; and it is a dreadful criſis that we are come to, if a man is to be criminated for a word.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You ſpoke of the Engliſh Delegates; you don't mean that they repreſented the people of England?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Certainly, only thoſe who ſent them; I underſtood that Mr. Margarot and Mr. Sinclair repreſented about 5000 people, and Mr. Brown about 5000 from Sheffield.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You have not poſitivey ſworn to the entire ſcroll of Minutes ſhewn to you; ſome part of it you don't acknowledge.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I can only ſwear to that that was wrote by myſelf; and ſo far as my ideas led me to think, I was right in writing them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Though the name of Minutes is given to them, are they, in fact, the Minutes of the Convention till they have received the reviſal of the Committee?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Certainly not; to correct and to expunge all errors whatever.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were they ever offered, or ſent forth to the world by way of publication?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not that I know of.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were they ever corrected by authority of the Convention?
A I never heard of it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are there any eraſures, any interlineations in them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Several emendations were made upon the motions of one or two Members; but when ſeveral emendation were propoſed, it was ſaid, you may leave that to the Committee.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: To the beſt of your recollection (I made a motion about the union of the two kingdoms), did it appear to you that that motion had a ſeditious tendency?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: On the contrary, I conceive it would be for the good of mankind, and the ſalvation of theſe kingdoms.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you look upon tocſin to be a French word?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe ſo: but I cannot ſay that it is: I never heard it made uſe of in the Convention.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are you ſure that it is not inſtead of one French word, two Chineſe words?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot ſay; I know nothing about the Chineſe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I have a notion 'tis; then, all the knowledge you gained of a Secret Committee, was the next day among the Sections, and among the Friends?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That reminds me of a miſtake I made before; for I find that I have recorded that very motion which Mr. Sinclair moved to be burnt, and which was afterwards agreed not to be burnt; and I heard further of the buſineſs next day.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: There was a motion made for a Convention of Emergency; did the Convention ever fix upon or delineate the plan by which they were to act, or did that Convention ever take place?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not that I know of.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: In joining the Friends of the People, and in joining the Britiſh Convention, for the purpoſe of obtaining a reform, did you think yourſelves warranted by the Conſtitution to endeavour to obtain a redreſs of grievances?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Perfectly; and I would think ſo ſtill, if I were to be ſent to Botany Bay for it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are thoſe grievances done away?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: By no means; and I am ſorry for it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are you of opinion, that if a Convention Bill was paſſed in the Britiſh Parliament, it would tend to leſſen thoſe grievances.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It would extend them tenfold.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What would be the conſequence of the ſuſpenſion of the Habeas Corpus act, and of the Act for preventing wrongous impriſonment?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It would be certainly a great encroachment upon the privilege of Britons.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Might not every peaceable inhabitant of theſe realms run great danger, in caſe of a foreign invaſion, of loſing his property, by the enemies plundering him of it, if they were ſucceſsful?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I have no doubt of that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you think it would be more conſtitutional in Engliſhmen, more conſtitutional in Scotchmen, more conſtitutional in Britons, to ſit idle and look at a foreign invaſion, or attend a Convention of Emergency.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I dare ſay the whole Court, and all the audience will agree, that to meet upon ſuch an occaſion, would be a work of neceſſity.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was foreign invaſion the expreſſion that was made uſe of, or was a French invaſion ever mentioned?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: As far as I recollect, French invaſion was mentioned in ſome perſon's motion; but I cannot ſay in whoſe motion, or whether it was in doors, or out of doors; or in the Convention, or out of the Convention, I cannot ſay.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Then you mean to ſay, that an Invaſion from France was uppermoſt in the minds of the Convention?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot ſay what was uppermoſt; but I know I have heard that expreſſion, but I believe it was out of the Convention.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was it cuſtomary for the motions to be handed to the table, which were not paſſed in the Convention?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Many ſuch were handed in, and many not paſſed, and not taken notice of at all.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are you certain, that the two motions ſhewn you juſt now, and which were indorſed by you, and, I preſume, were given into you in that manner, are you ſure they were ever read in the Convention?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Be ſo good as ſhew me them again (looks at them). One of theſe motions is certainly new to me ſince I came before the Court: a perſon might ſay to me, there is a queſtion concerning union, and I might indorſe it ſo without ever reading it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What was the mode of proceeding in opening and cloſing the buſineſs of the day?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: As the buſineſs of all Chriſtian people ſhould be, it was begun and ended by prayer.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ever obſerve any thing of a ſeditious or riotous appearance in the Convention?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt.
Did you ever hear any thing mentioned, or whiſpered in the Convention, that might tend to overturn the Conſtitution?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ever hear any thing mentioned there againſt the King?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ever hear any thing mentioned there againſt place-men and penſioners?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Often.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: That, I ſuppoſe, is the Sedition that is meant to be charged.

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: I thought it very hard that the Lord Advocate, when I was here before, ſhould charge me with falſhood. I hope he will not do ſo now.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What profeſſion are you of?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Clerk in the Gazetteer office.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How long have you been in that profeſſion?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Seven or eight years.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you a Member of the meeting of the Friends of the People?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you a Member of the Britiſh Convention?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Delegate from what ſociety?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: From the Canongate Society.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you act in any particular office in the Convention?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ſometimes acted as Aſſiſtant Secretary?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who elſe aſſiſted the Secretary?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Several perſons.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were there any perſons who wrote ſhort-hand and took down the debates?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, my brother.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Look at theſe Minutes, and ſee if you can find your own hand-writing?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you take down, to the beſt of your abilities, what did really paſs in the Convention?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I certainly would take nothing down that I thought improper.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And you would take down nothing but what paſſed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you recollect, if it was the practice at the commencement of the meeting, to read over the ſcroll of the Minutes?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I have ſeen it done ſometimes, and ſometimes not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you recollect whether it was ever uſual to correct them upon reading them over?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think, I recollect one night, there were ſome corrections.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are you acquainted with that Gentleman?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I have had the honour to ſee Mr. Margarot many times, and been in his company.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was he a Member of the Convention?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Have you heard him ſpeak?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I have heard him propoſe motions.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee him act as Chairman?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot recollect to a certainty, whether he was or not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you recollect any motion in the Convention with reſpect to a union between England and Scotland?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I recollect the union with the Societies of the Friends of the People in England.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Read that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: (Reads). Margarot moved, that a committee be appointed to conſider.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't recollect that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Whoſe hand-writing is it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I believe it is Mr. Aitcheſon's.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You recollect there was ſuch a motion?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, that there was a union to take place between the Engliſh ſocieties and the Scotch.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you remember any motion being made of a Convention of Emergency?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you remember any thing about the purpoſe of that Convention; of the events in which they were to meet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: To remonſtrate to Parliament againſt a Bill, ſuch as a Convention Bill.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were there any particular perſons who made a motion reſpecting it?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I believe it was made by Mr. Callendar.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you recollect that that motion was made?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: A. Yes it is my hand-writing.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you remember the events that were to happen.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That, in caſe of a Convention Bill, they were to meet in order to draw up a remonſtrance to Parliament.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was any other event mentioned? any thing about the Habeas Corpus Act?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't at preſent recollect.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you recollect any thing about a foreign invaſion, or any thing about foreign troops?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, about the Heſſians and Hanoverians being brought over.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You ſpoke about Mr. Callendar's motion: when was it taken up? the next day?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot ſay.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was the Convention uſed to take notice of the motions at the time they were made, or did they lie over?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They generally laid over.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was that motion of Mr. Callendar's taken up afterwards?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot ſay.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was there any debate about Mr. Callendar's motion reſpecting the Convention Bill? and recollect yourſelf before you give an anſwer?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot be particular.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were there any amendments propoſed to that motion?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I believe there were.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What reſolution was come to in conſequence of the amendment?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't know particularly; I don't recollect.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Is that your writing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, (reads). Citizen Sinclair read the amendments upon Citizen Callendar's motion; and then there comes ſome other perſon's writing; and, it was agreed, that the houſe ſhould reſolve itſelf into a Committee, to conſider of the amendments propoſed; the Convention being reſumed, and the amendments being read over, the members ſtood upon their legs, and ſolemnly and unanimouſly paſſed the following reſolution.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Now recollect yourſelf, and tell us what paſſed at that time. Was it a reſolution upon Citizen Callendar's motion?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Now recollect what that motion was?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot recollect.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Look if it is mentioned there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, there is a blank page follows it. The reſolution then paſſed, was reſerved to be entered 'till the end of the Minutes.

sp.speaker: Lord Advocate.
sp.p: It is very material that the Jury ſhould take down theſe words; for it is that upon which I ſhall found a very material part of what I ſhall have to ſay to them. Repeat it again.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think the Reſolution that was then paſſed, was left to be entered at the laſt part of the Minutes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Look, and ſee if you find any more blanks?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I believe there are not (looks over the Minutes). Yes, here is a blank of four lines.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you remember any propoſal being made about burning any part of the written evidence, or deſtroying any motion or reſolution the Convention had come to?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I don't recollect.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know Mr. Aitcheſon?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you recollect any objection being made by him to burning or deſtroying any reſolution that they might have come to?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I do not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you recollect any other perſon, a Member of that Convention, objecting to that meaſure?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not recollect any ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Burnet.
sp.p: Do you remember a motion being made for a Secret Committee?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Solicitor General.
sp.p: Who was it that propoſed that motion, which paſſed ſolemnly and unanimouſly?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot ſay.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the members all ſtand up when that motion paſſed ſo ſolemnly?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't recollect; but I ſhould ſuppoſe ſo, from what is written here.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you remember any thing about declaring before God and the world, any thing?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot ſay.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you remember any thing that was ſaid about calamitous circumſtances?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No; there was a reſolution in caſe of a Convention Bill.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you remember any thing about paying no regard to ſuch an act if it paſſed?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I never would agree to that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you remember any ſpeech or motion being made as to what the Convention were to do, upon the meeting being diſperſed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: If they were diſpered they were to meet in another place.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who was it that ſpoke with regard to that; did Mr. Margarot ſay any thing, or make a ſpeech upon that ſubject? recollect yourſelf?—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot recollect.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was is debated? Was there any difference of opinion upon that ſubject?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot recollect.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you remember any motion being made with regard to it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I believe there was.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was it Mr. Margarot that made the motion?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I am not very certain whether he did or not, but I rather ſuſpect he did.

sp.speaker: Q.
